citation.article-title: Recharacterization and emended description of the genus Mycoplana and description of two new species Mycoplana ramosa and Mycoplana segnis.

p.s: Description of Mycoplana segnis sp. nov.
Mycoplana segnis (seg'nis. L.adj. segnis, slow, sluggish, inactive)
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite.
The Voges-Proskauer test is negative (strain TK0059T does not grow in glucose phosphate broth).

Acid is produced from L-arabinose, D-xylose, D-glucose, D-mannose, D-fructose, D-galactose, maltose, sucrose, lactose, and trehalose oxidatively, but is not produced from D-sorbitol, D-mannitol, inositol, glycerol, and soluble starch.
The utilization of single carbon compounds and nitrogen compounds cannot be determined at this time, possibly because of axotrophy.
The DNA base composition ranges from 67 to 68 mol% G+C.
The major hydroxy fatty acid is 3-hydroxy-C12:0 acid.
The type strain is strain TK0059 (= ATCC 21756 = IFO 13240), which was isolated from soil by Takahashi and Komahara in 1973.
The DNA base composition of the type strain is 67.5 mol% G+C.
Strain TK0058 (= ATCC 21759 = IFO 13213), which was previously assigned to the species M. dimorpha, is a strain of M. segnis.
